ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The course is valuable for environment students because it helps you see the world from a different disciplinary perspective and think in new ways. Also valuable for history students because challenges conventional categories of historical analysis.Instructor was quite reticent at times and relied on the students to carry the discussion without really bothering to structure the discussion very much.
I felt the instructor could have put more effort into preparing for class, but overall it was a very good course.

The class discussions - people made interesting points.I enjoyed some of the readings very much, and enjoyed the flexibility of being able to pick my own topics on which to write papers.Was good learning about US history through the medium of environmental history (I'm not from the US)
The readings were quite interesting

The readings and the opportunity to go to and discuss the environmental history conferences. I also really enjoyed the opportunity to have Richard White visit the class--what a treat. Perhaps you might consider having such visits be a more integral aspect of the course. The other aspect of the course I enjoyed was the sparring between the historians and the foresters; it was quite informative. I hope you continue to keep the course open to both groups.
I really enjoyed the readings - particularly the books. I learned a tremendous amount from them about history and found them to be useful.
Having both history and forestry students in the class-provided new perspectives
I really enjoyed the readings

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I feel like the course got a bit repetitive towards the end of the term - we were discussing the same themes over again. If there were a way to bring in new themes for discussion, that would be good. Perhaps a more chronological structure might also help, to give students more of a sense of historical change in narratives/perspectives/human relationship with the environment.

This course is taught as a history class. The professor seemed to put little time into preparing to guide the discussion and instead let the discussion simply go where it would. As a seminar, I felt it devolved into various students simply pontificating.

Organization. Deadlines shifted around a bit so you were never quite sure when things were due, and the readings weren't always available. Discussions could have been better, but I think it depends a lot on who is in the class.

I believe that this class doesn't really work in its current format. While I appreciate the effort to integrate different disciplines, these are two fundamentally different groups trying to work together in one class. I certainly have plenty to learn about historiography and how this whole process works academically, but it is not beneficial to my career nor any of my fellow MEMs. I also felt that I didn't have much to contribute towards conversations when my fellow students are pursuing PHDs, in many cases specifically in environmental history. I haven't taken history class since 11th grade. I'd rather learn about environmental history and try to connect themes to current issues, whereas for an academic history phd student, they are at a completely different level. I think there is a real need for MEMs to develop their understanding of environmental history, but I believe it should occur in a different way.
The instructor's preparation for class

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: N/a - I didn't really ask for help

did not reach out to the professor; assignments were not always clear; more time could have been spent by the professor preparing for weekly class and clarifying expectations for the outside writing assignments.
The instructor was very available and very helpful

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course is related to my overall academic focus on environmental governance. It provided a good contrast to the other courses I'm taking because of its focus on history as a substantive focus and as a way of knowing.
It turned out to not really fit into my overall academic program

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn from the perspective of a new discipline. And the readings sounded interesting (and mostly were interesting).
I took this class to develop a grounded understanding of the history of where we are in time now and to understand the various perspectives and explanations for how we got to be here.
To read the historical literature and apply the readings to my own research interests.
I wanted to learn more about the history of the environment so I could make better decisions in my profession now and in the future
I wanted to learn about the literary and historic background of environmental studies

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Pretty much - though as mentioned above, it got a bit repetitive towards the end

Not really - it was strictly a history class. What was focused on was not the history but rather the manner in which we pursue historical inquiry. As such, the course seemed poorly suited to be joint-listed with FES, beyond the fact that it has "environmental" in the title.
Yes and no. It was all that I expected, but not as enlightening as I hoped it might be.
The reading definitely lived up to my expectations, but the class did not. I found myself increasingly disappointed with the discussions.
yes
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
no
Yes, I was able to read widely across the historical literature and have been able to apply the work to my own research.
I did, wish I had more time to do all the reading
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's very US-centric, but you could explore different geographical areas through the papers you write

The reading load is intensive. Do not take this course if you hope to better understand where we are and how we got here - it is exclusively focused on ideas about how to pursue historical scholarship.
Enjoy the readings, and come to class with questions and themes to discuss.
try to keep up with the reading and participate in class
